model.hed: Best Hotels and Resorts in Botswana: 2012
model.dek: Hotels and resorts in Botswana on Condé Nast Traveler's 2012 Gold List: The World's Best Places to Stay

items.name: Mombo Camp and Little Mombo
items.description: Expect to see lions, leopards, zebras, and more on the game drives of this two-part camp near bush, plains, and wetlands. Comfort is the norm inside the tents, which are elevated into the tree canopy and have wood beams, outdoor showers, and private verandas. Meals exceed expectations and are served anywhere on the property.

items.name: Jack's Camp, Kalahari
items.description: "Gorgeously sited" on a low grassland knoll among desert palms and Kalahari acacia, this camp in the Makgadikgadi Salt Pans comprises green canvas tents and a main canvas pavilion for communal meals. Tents have Persian rugs, en-suite bathrooms, indoor and outdoor showers, and a veranda. Designated a Natural History Museum of Botswana because of its many artifacts and local stone tools, the central mess tent serves three-course meals such as fresh tomato and basil soup followed by ostrich piccata and roast Botswana beef. Nibble on homemade chicken pies and lemon-curd biscuits at afternoon tea after drives spotting lions, hyenas, and meerkats.

items.name: Sanctuary Chobe Chilwero, Chobe
items.description: The name of this camp above the Chobe River is fitting—it translates as "place of high views." "Extremely comfortable" earth-tone cottages have thatched roofs, air-conditioning, and private gardens with hammocks, and blend British colonial and African influences. Baths have freestanding tubs that look out across the floodplains, "where hundreds of elephants are moving about—it’s truly amazing." The spa offers Vichy showers and treatments in a treetop room. Guides lead groups on game drives to spot lions and hippos, before dinners of local dishes made with crocodile and impala.

items.name: Camp Okavango
items.description: The thatched main lodge shaded by mangosteen trees sits amid floodplains and savannahs. "Very comfortable safari-style tents" on teak platforms have sliding doors leading to decks. "Outstanding staff make many different activities possible," including a boat trip to "an island visited by elephants." Meals depend on seasonal ingredients and include dishes like kudu steak.

items.name: DumaTau
items.description: Ten tented suites on the Linyanti River in northern Botswana's Linyanti Wildlife Reserve, home to lions, leopards, cheetahs, and wild dogs.

fields.title: [DumaTau Camp](/hotels/africa-middle-east/botswana/dumatau-camp-linyanti-wildlife-reserve-botswana)
fields.caption:
Ten tented suites on the Linyanti River in northern Botswana’s Linyanti Wildlife Reserve, home to lions, leopards, cheetahs, and wild dogs. Completely rebuilt on a pristine site to eco-wise specs, this solar-powered camp has inviting areas for lounging and dining with sweeping river views, an open-air bar, and a sociable fire pit. Action-packed days are filled with game drives, walks, birding, boating, and catch-and-release fishing. Khaki rules—albeit 50 shades of muted, textured khaki, greige, and bone, all reflecting the sun-bleached surroundings.





[read more](/hotels/africa-middle-east/botswana/dumatau-camp-linyanti-wildlife-reserve-botswana)

items.name: Jao Camp, Okavango Delta
items.description: At tents on raised platforms, guests retire to their salas for an afternoon siesta overlooking the floodplains. The perfect-scoring location on an island in the Okavango Delta—with waterways, lagoons, and Kalahari grasslands—"literally takes your breath away." Game drives take in lechwes, lions, elephants, and leopards.

items.name: Khwai River Lodge, Okavango Delta
items.description: This lodge opened by the first president of Botswana is set under a canopy of leadwood and fig trees, and overlooks a floodplain in the Okavango Delta. Its thatched-roof tents have private decks and display "traditional African decor," with wood-and-leather furnishings. Game drives take in black rhinos, hornbills, and elephant shrews. African and international menus emphasize locally sourced ingredients.

items.name: Abu Camp, Okavango Delta
items.description: Six tented suites on the edge of a lagoon in a 450,000-acre private game reserve. A contemporary interpretation of the classic safari aesthetic, seamlessly integrated into the natural environment. Each suite is individually decorated in calming colors that mirror the sun-bleached landscape.

items.name: Little Vumbura Camp
items.description: "My favorite camp, bar none." At this tented camp on an island in the northern part of the Okavango Delta, guests divide their time between water-based activities, such as wildlife viewing in mokoros, and game drives to see lions, leopards, elephants, sable, and buffalo. "Great tents" have en-suite facilities, wood-plank floors, canopied beds with mosquito nets, and terraces with views to the horizon. Guests congregate around the plunge pool and in the reading area, where cobalt-blue sofas overlook the plains. Menus are customized each day based on guests' preferences. "Everything exceeded our expectations."

items.name: Sanctuary Chief's Camp
items.description: On the northwestern tip of Chief's Island, shaded by jackalberry, sausage and rain trees, these 12 thatched-roof pavilions have private viewing decks with hammocks. In addition to traditional jeep game drives to view the Big Five, take a ride aboard a mokoro—a dugout canoe— to spot wildlife such as lions and zebras.

items.name: andBeyond Sandibe Okavango Safari Lodge
items.description:
Opened in 2014, under the andBeyond banner.

__What?__ Set on a private concession, adjacent to wildlife-rich Moremi Game Reserve, this lodge was completely rebuilt and reopened in late 2014. A striking series of decks, indoor/outdoor lounges, pathways, and modern, curved, wooden rooftops (all inspired by nests of golden weaver birds) make this a safari experience far from ordinary.

__Get me there now!__ With only 8 suites, book well in advance. Flights to the nearby Chitabe Airstrip can be had from Maun or Kasane airports with connecting flights from Gabarone or Johannesburg.

items.name: Savute Elephant Camp
items.description: Watch elephants grazing at this camp that is the "epitome of rustic elegance." Set on the Savute River, hacienda-style tents on raised wooden platforms have viewing decks with hammocks and "a large four-poster bed draped with mosquito netting." Guests and "very knowledgeable guides" spot antelopes, lions, and leopards in addition to pachyderms. The restaurant overlooks the river.

items.name: Savuti Camp, Linyanti
items.description: This camp lures guests with the wildlife on the Savute Channel and its surrounding grasslands. Day and night drives led by "super-friendly staff" bring visitors close to lions, leopards, cheetahs, giraffes, and spotted hyenas. The seven large tents are "comfortable and decorative," raised off the ground and facing the plains, and have terraces with sofas, thatched roofs, picture windows, and gauzy fabrics. Each tent is connected to the main area—where the bar, dining room, and lounges are—by wooden walkways. "Exceptional meals are customized daily" based on guests' preferences.

items.name: Selinda Camp, Selinda Reserve
items.description: Located in a 500-square-mile elephant-rich reserve, Selinda Camp—co-owned by Beverly and Dereck Joubert, the famed African wildlife documentarians—has been re_imagined with open-air thatched areas furnished with leather sofas, chaises made from traditional mokoros (dugout canoes), and a long dining table that overlooks a hippo-filled marsh. Inside the nine spacious, elevated tents, reed_covered canvas walls enclose a king-size bed, a writing nook, and a sitting area. The tub in the gargantuan bathroom out back makes for perfect soaking after a late_afternoon game drive. Following a dinner of grilled ostrich and triple-death chocolate mousse, hope that the self-anointed Selinda Choir (the entire staff) will break into an impromptu song and dance.

items.name: Vumbura Plains, Okavango Delta
items.description: "Each night, the sounds of Africa are amazing" at this camp among wild fig and sausage trees—a location that scores perfectly. The camp’s two sections both have elevated dining areas and views of a wildlife-frequented watering hole. Perfect-scoring design includes open-plan thatched-roof villas with kiaat-wood vanities and plunge pools. Guides help guests see "every animal imaginable."

items.name: Xaranna Okavango Delta Camp
items.description: Secluded on its own island (arrival is by motorboat most of the year), this nine-tent camp within a roughly 62,000-acre private concession in the southern Okavango Delta is one of two camps there by &Beyond (formerly CCAfrica). Water lilies, hippos, frogs, and other creatures provide inspiration for Xaranna’s playful decor (think funky embroidered lily pad–shaped cushions and fat-bottomed hippo side tables). Each air-conditioned tent has a bathroom with a nifty dressing room, freestanding tub, and walk-in shower that leads outdoors to another shower and an infinity pool big enough for laps. Camp life involves not much more than drifting down reed-lined waterways in a makoro, watching for hippo and elephant crossings while appreciating the beauty in the details: hundreds of iridescent dragonflies and jewel-bright kingfishers darting in and out of the reeds. The chorus of thousands of painted reed frogs will lull you to sleep after a dinner of sweet potato soup, chicken fajitas, and chocolate fondue.

items.name: Zarafa Camp
items.description: Your first glimpse of the terrain from Zarafa’s lofty, canvas-roofed reception area—a sweeping vista of a lagoon and the palm-studded floodplains beyond—is nothing short of stunning. The 300,000-acre Selinda Reserve’s flagship camp comprises four massive tents, each outfitted with a grand copper tub and a plunge pool. In remaking this camp (formerly Zibadianja), the owners, documentary filmmakers Beverly and Dereck Joubert, took great pains to be gentle on the environment without forsaking luxury. Floors are fashioned from the recycled teakwood of railway sleeper cars; there’s an on-site water-filtration plant; and the electricity flows 24/7 from solar panels, making Zarafa Africa’s first luxe camp powered only by the sun. Another likely first: Guests get a Canon D40 and lenses to use during their stay, and the photos—which typically star some of Selinda’s 9,000 elephants—are downloaded onto CDs as souvenirs. The Jouberts’ touch can be felt everywhere: He chose the site; she created the decor and the menu, which includes dishes such as prune-stuffed turkey breast and marula mustard lamb tagine—all served on jackalberry--shaded teak decks.
